headline: CNN News Central
subHeadline: Possible Shutdown Comes At A Delicate Time For The U.S. Economy; Soldier Who Crossed Into N. Korea Returns To U.S.; Baltimore PD Reveals New Details About Tech CEO Murder. Aired 11:30a-12p ET

utterances.speaker: JOHN BERMAN, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: The last thing it needs. And remember a short economy, bad. But a long shutdown, very potentially -- (INAUDIBLE)

utterances.speaker: EGAN
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. The longer it goes on, the bigger the impact, John.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: All right. Matt Egan, great to see you.

utterances.speaker: EGAN
utterances.sentences: Thanks. BERMAN

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Intense diplomacy. That is what U.S. officials are saying led to Army Private Travis King getting out of North Korea and back into U.S. custody. We have video in from just overnight early this morning that shows King arriving back on American soil weeks after he seemingly voluntarily crossed into North Korea. Now that he is safe, a very big question is what happens to him now considering how extraordinary the circumstances were that he ended up in North Korea in the first place.Let's go over to CNN's Oren Liebermann. He has much more on this. Oren, are you hearing anything about what kind of trouble King could be in now and also what is happening with him right now?

utterances.speaker: OREN LIEBERMANN, CNN PENTAGON CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Well, Kate, right now, he's at Brooke Army Medical Center after landing at Joint Base San Antonio early, early this morning. Worth noting the Brooke Army Medical Center is where you're taken if you've been detained overseas.It's where you re-acclimate, where you get a medical evaluation, perhaps a psychiatric evaluation as well. It is for example, where Brittney Griner and Trevor Reed were taken after they were detained in Russia. So, that's where he is now and where he'll stay for at least some time but how long exactly, is unclear. As you point out, the big question is what happens next? Officials had raised the possibility that he fought -- could face further disciplinary action after returning to the U.S. right? He was absent without leave after the officials here at the Pentagon said he willfully and intentionally crossed into North Korea, an adversary state. But the army pushing off that question right now saying, look, we're going to deal with administrative actions later. Right now, it's a focus on making sure he recovers. But it's a difficult situation either way. He has just spent some 70 days in North Korean detention. And the question of whether to bring charges against him under the Uniform Code of Military Justice is not a simple one. At the same time, Kate, you certainly don't want to tell the president that there is no consequence for going absent without leave. But this is a decision the army has to make and probably has to make soon.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: It's a great point. Oren, thank you so much for the update. Sara? SARA SIDNER, CNN ANCHOR

utterances.speaker: POLO SANDOVAL, CNN CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Hi, Sara.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Polo, tell me a little bit about this. It appears that Governor Abbott is thumbing his nose at the New York mayor.

utterances.speaker: SANDOVAL
utterances.sentences: Bringing his message to the mayor's doorstep --

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SANDOVAL
utterances.sentences: That number was estimated to be about 15,000 last week. Yesterday, we heard from city officials here in New York saying that that number is now closer to 22,000. So, that's certainly a positive update, which means that that presumably, could be about 22,000 Venezuelan asylum seekers here in New York City that could potentially apply for TPS and the work authorization.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: And that means they can get jobs, correct? Yes. They're not --

utterances.speaker: SANDOVAL
utterances.sentences: That is the way it's supposed to work, yes.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Yes. And that was the big thing. And it's extremely expensive to live here as well.

utterances.speaker: SANDOVAL
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Polo Sandoval, thank you for breaking all that down for me.

utterances.speaker: SANDOVAL
utterances.sentences: Exactly, yes.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: All right, John.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: All right. This morning, Baltimore police revealing new details about the murder of a young tech CEO. Officer announced this morning that they caught the suspected killer. And we're learning this is not the first time the suspect has been behind bars.Omar Jimenez has been following this from the beginning. Omar, brings us up to speed.

utterances.speaker: OMAR JIMENEZ, CNN CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Yes. So, right now, they're in the middle of a press conference giving some new details. One, about his capture. So, this was a days-long manhunt and we understand that he was captured overnight in Bowie, Maryland, which is essentially between Baltimore and Washington, DC.He was taken into custody without incident, as we understand. But of course, him being on the loose given what he was accused of doing scared this community for four days at this point. Of course, he's suspected of killing 26-year-old Baltimore tech CEO Pava LaPere. And in that particular case, he was reported missing early Monday, and then her body was found later on after that. Now, you mentioned he is no stranger to law enforcement essentially at this point. Not only when you look back years, but just last week, he was a suspect in an attempted murder and arson case.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Last week?

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: Last week, as we understand from police, about a mile away from where LaPere's body was found. Now, police as we just learned, said that that was a more targeted incident that this suspect they believe knew some of the people affected there. And this one, we're still waiting to hear from the police how he may have or may have not known his particular -- this particular victim as well.But obviously, a lot of details. And as police were looking for LaPere -- for excuse me, Billingsley -- Jason Billingsley is the suspect here, there's also a vigil being held for the 26-year-old LaPere where her father was leading people in who she was. Someone who he said her presence will never leave the city of Baltimore and someone who transitioned from being basically going to -- transitioning him from being someone who's just a father to essentially being the father of a girl boss because of how much she was able to achieve. But at the end of the day, while we're still learning new details, this suspect is behind bars. And the last thing I'll say is he was sentenced to 30 years in prison back in 2015. But as we just learned, the -- about a lot of the sentence was taken out or suspended based on what was handed down at sentencing. So, he really only got 14 years. And then based on the sentencing guidelines and the law in Maryland, he was able to get out on some good behavior. But it is something that Baltimore officials are clearly upset about that he was able to be back out on the street.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: And they're actually answering questions about that right now.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: We'll get much more information as soon as it comes in. Omar, thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: Of course.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Sara.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Such a loss. Are you going to read more stories? Because you just had like 12 stories right there. Can you do more?

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: I'm exhausted. And I even did it walking --

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Well, lie down.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: -- while Mike was walking backward. (INAUDIBLE)

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: 14 stories there.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: This is called varsity anchoring, people. You know it's hard.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: You can our Dumbledore by sitting down and watching with your kids. No?

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: We're still finishing the last book, so we will --

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Oh. We will. So, so good.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, all so good.
